This adjustment is reasonable when you want your inferences to apply to a population that is not necessarily balanced but has the margins observed in OM-data-set.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Produces ODS statistical graphics of the distribution of estimable functions if the procedure performs the analysis in a sampling-based mode.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that the default plots corresponding to this LSMEANS statement be produced.

arguments.name: BOXPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: BOXPLOT<boxplot-options>> Produces box plots of the distribution of the least squares mean or least squares mean differences across a posterior sample. For example, this plot is available in procedures that support a Bayesian analysis through the BAYES statement. A separate box is generated for each estimable function, and all boxes appear on a single graph by default. You can affect the appearance of the box plot graph with the following options: ORIENTATION=VERTICAL|HORIZONTAL ORIENT=VERT|HORIZ specifies the orientation of the boxes. The default is vertical orientation of the box plots. NPANELPOS=number specifies how to break the series of box plots across multiple panels. If the NPANELPOS option is not specified, or if number equals zero, then all box plots are displayed in a single graph; this is the default.

arguments.name: DISTPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: DISTPLOT<distplot-options> Generates panels of histograms with a kernel density overlaid if the analysis has access to a set of posterior parameter estimates. You can sepcify the following distplot-options in parentheses: BOX|NOBOX controls the display of a horizontal box plot of the estimable function’s distribution across the posterior sample below the graph. The BOX option is enabled by default. HIST|NOHIST controls the display of the histogram of the estimable function’s distribution across the posterior sample. The HIST option is enabled by default. NORMAL|NONORMAL controls the display of a normal density estimate on the graph. The NONORMAL option is enabled by default. KERNEL|NOKERNEL controls the display of a kernel density estimate on the graph. The KERNEL option is enabled by default. NROWS=number specifies the highest number of rows in a panel. The default is 3. NCOLS=number specifies the highest number of columns in a panel. The default is 3. UNPACK unpacks the panel into separate graphics.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking as documented for the ESTIMATE statement.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN
arguments.description: Requests that multiplicity adjustments for the p-values of estimates be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. Step-down methods increase the power of multiple testing procedures by taking advantage of the fact that a p-value is never declared significant unless all smaller p-values are also declared significant. You can specify the following step-down-options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. The default is MAXTIME=60. ORDER=PVALUE ORDER=ROWS specifies the order in which the step-down tests are performed. ORDER=PVALUE is the default, with LS-mean estimates being declared significant only if all LS-mean estimates with smaller (unadjusted) p-values are significant. If you specify ORDER=ROWS, then significances are evaluated in the order in which they are specified. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

arguments.name: TESTVALUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the value under the null hypothesis for testing the estimable functions in the LSMESTIMATE statement. The rules for specifying the value-list are very similar to those for specifying the divisor list in the DIVISOR= option. If no TESTVALUE= is specified, all tests are performed as H: Lβ=0. Missing values in the value-list also are translated to zeros. If you specify fewer values than rows in the ESTIMATE statement, the last value in value-list is carried forward. The TESTVALUE= option affects only p-values from individual, joint, and multiplicity-adjusted tests. It does not affect confidence intervals.

arguments.name: UPPER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values greater than the test statistic. A two-tailed test is the default. An upper-tailed confidence limit is also produced if you specify the CL or ALPHA= option.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the response, or dependent variable, and the effects, or explanatory variables. If you omit the explanatory variables, the procedure fits an intercept-only model. An intercept term is included in the model by default. The intercept can be removed with the NOINT option. You can specify the response in the form of a single variable or in the form of a ratio of two variables denoted events/trials. The first form is applicable to all responses. The second form is applicable only to summarized binomial response data. When each observation in the input data set contains the number of events (for example, successes) and the number of trials from a set of binomial trials, use the events/trials syntax. In the events/trials model syntax, you specify two variables that contain the event and trial counts. These two variables are separated by a slash (/). The values of both events and (trialsevents) must be nonnegative, and the value of the trials variable must be greater than 0 for an observation to be valid. The variable events or trials can take noninteger values.

arguments.name: AGGREGATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the subpopulations on which the Pearson chi-square and the deviance are calculated. Specifying the AGGREGATE option is equivalent to specifying the AGGREGATE= option with a variable list that includes all explanatory variables in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Sets the confidence coefficient for parameter confidence intervals to 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1. The default value of number is 0.05.

arguments.name: CICONV=
arguments.description: Sets the convergence criterion for profile likelihood confidence intervals.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that confidence limits for predicted values be displayed (see the OBSTATS option).

arguments.name: CODING=
arguments.description: Specifies that effect coding be used for all classification variables in the model. This is the same as specifying PARAM=EFFECT as a CLASS statement option.

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: CODING=EFFECT

arguments.name: FULLRANK
arguments.description: CODING=FULLRANK

arguments.name: CONVERGE=
arguments.description: Sets the convergence criterion. The value of number must be between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: CONVH=
arguments.description: Sets the relative Hessian convergence criterion. The value of number must be between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Requests that the parameter estimate correlation matrix be displayed.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Requests that the parameter estimate covariance matrix be displayed.

arguments.name: DIAGNOSTICS
arguments.description: Requests that case deletion diagnostic statistics be displayed (see the OBSTATS option).

arguments.name: DIST=
arguments.description: Specifies the built-in probability distribution to use in the model.
arguments.help: DIST=BINOMIAL | GAMMA | GEOMETRIC | IGAUSSIAN | MULTINOMIAL | NEGBIN | NORMAL | POISSON | ZIP

arguments.name: BINOMIAL
arguments.description: Binomial distribution

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Gamma distribution

arguments.name: GEOMETRIC
arguments.description: Geometric distribution

arguments.name: IGAUSSIAN
arguments.description: Inverse Gaussian distribution

arguments.name: MULTINOMIAL
arguments.description: Multinomial distribution

arguments.name: NEGBIN
arguments.description: Negative binomial distribution

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Normal distribution

arguments.name: POISSON
arguments.description: Poisson distribution

arguments.name: DSCALE
arguments.description: Same as specifying SCALE=DEVIANCE or SCALE=D. This fixes the scale parameter at a value of 1 in the estimation procedure.

arguments.name: EXACTMAX
arguments.description: Names a variable used for performing an exact Poisson regression. For each observation, the integer part of the EXACTMAX value should be nonnegative and at least as large as the response value. If the EXACTMAX option is specified without a variable, then default values are computed.

arguments.name: EXPECTED
arguments.description: Requests that the expected Fisher information matrix be used to compute parameter estimate covariances and the associated statistics.

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Sets initial values for parameter estimates in the model.

arguments.name: INTERCEPT=
arguments.description: Initializes the intercept term to number for parameter estimation.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Displays the iteration history for all iterative processes: parameter estimation, fitting constrained models for contrasts and Type 3 analyses, and profile likelihood confidence intervals.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the link function to use in the model.
arguments.help: LINK=CUMCLL | CUMLOGIT | CUMPROBIT | CLOGLOG | IDENTITY | LOG | LOGIT | PROBIT | POWER(number)

arguments.name: CUMCLL
arguments.description: Cumulative complementary log-log function

arguments.name: CUMLOGIT
arguments.description: Cumulative logit function

arguments.name: CUMPROBIT
arguments.description: Cumulative probit function

arguments.name: CLOGLOG
arguments.description: Complementary log-log function

arguments.name: IDENTITY
arguments.description: Identity function

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Log function

arguments.name: LOGIT
arguments.description: Logit function

arguments.name: PROBIT
arguments.description: Probit function

arguments.name: POWER
arguments.description: Power with λ=number function

arguments.name: LRCI
arguments.description: Requests that two-sided confidence intervals for all model parameters be computed based on the profile likelihood function.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Sets the maximum allowable number of iterations for all iterative computation processes in PROC GENMOD. By default, MAXITER=50.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Requests that no intercept term be included in the model. An intercept is included unless this option is specified.

arguments.name: NOSCALE
arguments.description: Holds the scale parameter fixed. Otherwise, for the normal, inverse Gaussian, and gamma distributions, the scale parameter is estimated by maximum likelihood. If you omit the SCALE= option, the scale parameter is fixed at the value 1.

arguments.name: OBSTATS
arguments.description: Specifies that an additional table of statistics be displayed.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as an offset variable.

arguments.name: PREDICTED
arguments.description: Requests that predicted values, the linear predictor, its standard error, and the Hessian weight be displayed (see the OBSTATS option).

arguments.name: RESIDUALS
arguments.description: Requests that residuals and standardized residuals be displayed.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Sets the value used for the scale parameter where the NOSCALE option is used.

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Replace number with an actual scale parameter value.

arguments.name: PEARSON
arguments.description: Fixes the scale parameter at the value 1 in the estimation procedure. After the parameter estimates are determined, the exponential family dispersion parameter is assumed to be given by Pearson’s chi-square statistic divided by the degrees of freedom.

arguments.name: DEVIANCE
arguments.description: Fixes the scale parameter at a value of 1 in the estimation procedure. After the parameter estimates are determined, the exponential family dispersion parameter is assumed to be given by the deviance divided by the degrees of freedom.

arguments.name: SCORING=
arguments.description: Requests that on iterations up to number, the Hessian matrix be computed using the Fisher scoring method.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Sets the tolerance for testing singularity of the information matrix and the crossproducts matrix.

arguments.name: TYPE1
arguments.description: Requests that a Type 1, or sequential, analysis be performed.

arguments.name: TYPE3
arguments.description: Requests that statistics for Type 3 contrasts be computed for each effect specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests Wald statistics for Type 3 contrasts. You must also specify the TYPE3 option in order to compute Type 3 Wald statistics.

arguments.name: WALDCI
arguments.description: Requests that two-sided Wald confidence intervals for all model parameters be computed based on the asymptotic normality of the parameter estimators.

arguments.name: XVARS
arguments.description: Requests that the regression variables be included in the OBSTATS table.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set that contains all the variables in the input data set and, optionally, the estimated linear predictors (XBETA) and their standard error estimates, the weights for the Hessian matrix, predicted values of the mean, confidence limits for predicted values, residuals, and case deletion diagnostics. Residuals and diagnostic statistics are not computed for multinomial models.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the output data set. If you omit the OUT=option, the output data set is created and given a default name that uses the DATA convention.

arguments.name: CH=
arguments.description: [Requires REPEATED statement] Represents the leverage of a cluster.

arguments.name: CLUSTER
arguments.description: [Requires REPEATED statement] Represents the numerical cluster index, in order of sorted clusters.

arguments.name: DCLS=
arguments.description: [Requires REPEATED statement] Represents the Cook distance type statistic to measure the influence of deleting an entire cluster on the overall model fit.

arguments.name: DFBETA=
arguments.description: Represents the effect of deleting an observation on parameter estimates.

arguments.name: DFBETAC=
arguments.description: [Requires REPEATED statement] Represents the effect of deleting an entire cluster on parameter estimates.

arguments.name: DFBETACS=
arguments.description: [Requires REPEATED statement] Represents the effect of deleting an entire cluster on normalized parameter estimates.

arguments.name: DFBETAS=
arguments.description: Represents the effect of deleting an observation on standardized parameter estimates.

arguments.name: DOBS=
arguments.description: Represents the Cook distance type statistic to measure the influence of deleting a single observation on the overall model fit.

arguments.name: HESSWGT=
arguments.description: Represents the diagonal element of the weight matrix used in computing the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: LEVERAGE=
arguments.description: Represents the leverage of a single observation.

arguments.name: LOWER=
arguments.description: Represents the lower confidence limit for the predicted value of the mean, or the lower confidence limit for the probability that the response is less than or equal to the value of Level or Value.

arguments.name: MCLS=
arguments.description: [Requires REPEATED statement] Represents the studentized Cook distance type statistic to measure the influence of deleting an entire cluster on the overall model fit.

arguments.name: PREDICTED=
arguments.description: Represents the predicted value of the mean of the response or the predicted probability that the response variable is less than or equal to the value of Level or Value if the multinomial model for ordinal data is used.

arguments.name: PZERO=
arguments.description: Represents the zero-inflation probability for zero-inflated models.

arguments.name: RESCHI=
arguments.description: Represents the Pearson (chi) residual for identifying observations that are poorly accounted for by the model.

arguments.name: RESDEV=
arguments.description: Represents the deviance residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: RESLIK=
arguments.description: Represents the likelihood residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: RESRAW=
arguments.description: Represents the raw residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: STDRESCHI=
arguments.description: Represents the standardized Pearson (chi) residual for identifying observations that are poorly accounted for by the model.

arguments.name: STDRESDEV=
arguments.description: Represents the standardized deviance residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: STDXBETA=
arguments.description: Represents the standard error estimate of XBETA (see the XBETA keyword).

arguments.name: UPPER=
arguments.description: Represents the upper confidence limit for the predicted value of the mean, or the upper confidence limit for the probability that the response is less than or equal to the value of Level or Value.

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Represents the estimate of the linear predictor x'iB for observation i, or aj + x'iB, where j is the corresponding ordered value of the response variable for the multinomial model with ordinal data.

statements.name: REPEATED
statements.description: The REPEATED statement specifies the covariance structure of multivariate responses for GEE model fitting in the GENMOD procedure.

arguments.name: SUBJECT=
arguments.description: Identifies subjects in the input data set.

arguments.name: ALPHAINIT=
arguments.description: Specifies initial values for log odds ratio regression parameters if the LOGOR= option is specified for binary data.

arguments.name: CONVERGE=
arguments.description: Specifies the convergence criterion for GEE parameter estimation.

arguments.name: CORRW
arguments.description: Displays the estimated regression parameter correlation matrix. Both model-based and empirical correlations are displayed.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Displays the estimated regression parameter covariance matrix. Both model-based and empirical covariances are displayed.

arguments.name: ECORRB
arguments.description: Displays the estimated regression parameter empirical correlation matrix.

arguments.name: ECOVB
arguments.description: Displays the estimated regression parameter empirical covariance matrix.

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies initial values of the regression parameters estimation, other than the intercept parameter, for GEE estimation.

arguments.name: INTERCEPT=
arguments.description: Specifies either an initial or a fixed value of the intercept regression parameter in the GEE model.

arguments.name: LOGOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the regression structure of the log odds ratio used to model the association of the responses from subjects for binary data.
arguments.help: LOGOR=EXCH | FULLCLUST | LOGORVAR(variable) | NESTK | NEST1 | ZFULL | ZREP<(*matrix*)>

arguments.name: EXCH
arguments.description: Exchangeable

arguments.name: FULLCLUST
arguments.description: Fully parameterized clusters

arguments.name: LOGORVAR
arguments.description: Indicator variable for specifying block effects

arguments.name: NESTK
arguments.description: k-nested

arguments.name: NEST1
arguments.description: 1-nested

arguments.name: ZFULL
arguments.description: Fully specified z-matrix specified in ZDATA= data set

arguments.name: ZREP
arguments.description: Single cluster specification for replicated z-matrix specified in ZDATA= data set.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations allowed in the iterative GEE estimation process. The default number is 50.

arguments.name: MCORRB
arguments.description: Displays the estimated regression parameter model-based correlation matrix.

arguments.name: MCOVB
arguments.description: Displays the estimated regression parameter model-based covariance matrix.

arguments.name: MODELSE
arguments.description: Displays an analysis of parameter estimates table that uses model-based standard errors for inference.

arguments.name: PRINTMLE
arguments.description: Displays an analysis of maximum likelihood parameter estimates table. The maximum likelihood estimates are not displayed unless this option is specified.

arguments.name: RUPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of iterations between updates of the working correlation matrix.

arguments.name: SORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that the input data are grouped by subject and sorted within subject.

arguments.name: SUBCLUSTER=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable defining subclusters for the 1-nested or k-nested log odds ratio association modeling structures.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the structure of the working correlation matrix used to model the correlation of the responses from subjects.
arguments.help: TYPE=AR | EXCH | IND | MDEP(number) | UNSTR | USER | FIXED (matrix)

arguments.name: AR
arguments.description: Autoregressive(1)

arguments.name: EXCH
arguments.description: Exchangeable

arguments.name: IND
arguments.description: Independent

arguments.name: MDEP
arguments.description: m-dependent with m=number

arguments.name: UNSTR
arguments.description: Unstructured

arguments.name: USER
arguments.description: Fixed, user-specified correlation matrix

arguments.name: FIXED
arguments.description: Fixed, user-specified correlation matrix

arguments.name: V6CORR
arguments.description: Specifies that the SAS ‘Version 6’ method of computing the normalized Pearson chi-square be used for working correlation estimation and for model-based covariance matrix scale factor.

arguments.name: WITHINSUBJECT=
arguments.description: Defines an effect specifying the order of measurements within subjects.

arguments.name: YPAIR=
arguments.description: Specifies the variables in the ZDATA= data set corresponding to pairs of responses for log odds ratio association modeling.

arguments.name: ZDATA=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS data set containing either the full z-matrix for log odds ratio association modeling or the z-matrix for a single complete cluster to be replicated for all clusters.

arguments.name: ZROW=
arguments.description: Specifies the variables in the ZDATA= data set corresponding to rows of the z-matrix for log odds ratio association modeling.

statements.name: SLICE
statements.description: The SLICE statement provides a general mechanism for performing a partitioned analysis of the LS-means for an interaction. This analysis is also known as an analysis of simple effects. The SLICE statement uses the same options as the LSMEANS statement.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the LS-mean effect in the "Type III Tests of Fixed Effects" table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across LS-mean differences.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the differences of LS-means.
arguments.help: ADJUST=BON | DUNNETT | NELSON | SCHEFFE | SIDAK | SIMULATE | SMM | TUKEY

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: DUNNETT
arguments.description: Dunnett adjustment (in which the procedure analyzes all differences with a control level)

arguments.name: NELSON
arguments.description: Nelson adjustment (in which ANOM differences are taken)

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector. Syntax: SIMULATE<(simoptions)> You can specify the following simoptions in parentheses after the ADJUST=SIMULATE option. ACC=value specifies the target accuracy radius γ of a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. EPS=value specifies the value ε for a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. NSAMP=n specifies the sample size for the simulation. SEED=number specifies an integer that is used to start the pseudo-random number generator for the simulation. THREADS specifies that the computational work for the simulation be divided into parallel threads, where the number of threads is the value of the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=. NOTHREADS specifies that the computational work for the simulation be performed in sequence rather than in parallel. NOTHREADS is the default. This option overrides the SAS system option THREADS|NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: SMM
arguments.description: SMM adjustment

arguments.name: TUKEY
arguments.description: If your data are unbalanced, PROC GLIMMIX uses the approximation described in Kramer (1956) and identifies the adjustment as "Tukey-Kramer" in the results.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the LS-means with confidence level (1-number)x100%. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05.

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Modifies the values of the covariates that are used in computing LS-means. By default, all covariate effects are set equal to their mean values for computation of standard LS-means. The AT option enables you to assign arbitrary values to the covariates. Additional columns in the output table indicate the values of the covariates.

arguments.name: BYLEVEL
arguments.description: Requests that separate margins be computed for each level of the SLICE model-effect.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the LS-means. The confidence level is 0.95 by default; this can be changed with the ALPHA= option.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits. The default is the denominator degrees of freedom taken from the "Type III Tests" table that corresponds to the LS-means effect.

arguments.name: DIFF=
arguments.description: Requests that differences of the LS-means be displayed.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all pairwise differences; this is the default.

arguments.name: ANOM
arguments.description: Requests differences between each LS-mean and the average LS-mean, as in the analysis of means (Ott 1967).

arguments.name: CONTROL
arguments.description: Requests the differences with a control, which, by default, is the first level of each of the specified SLICE effects.

arguments.name: CONTROLL
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly smaller than the control; the upper confidence limits for the control minus the noncontrol levels are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: CONTROLU
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly larger than the control; the upper confidence limits for the noncontrol levels minus the control are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L matrix coefficients for the SLICE effects be displayed.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Requests exponentiation of the LS-means or LS-mean differences. When you model data with the logit, cumulative logit, or generalized logit link functions, and the estimate represents a log odds ratio or log cumulative odds ratio, the EXP option produces an odds ratio. In proportional hazards model, the exponentiation of the LS-mean differences produces estimates of hazard ratios. If you specify the CL or ALPHA= option, the (adjusted) confidence bounds are also exponentiated.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that estimates and their standard errors in the "Least Squares Means" table also be reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: LINES
arguments.description: Presents results of comparisons between all pairs of least squares means by listing the means in descending order and indicating nonsignificant subsets by line segments beside the corresponding LS-means.

arguments.name: MEANS
arguments.description: Specifies to produce the table of least squares means.

arguments.name: NOF
arguments.description: Suppresses the F test for testing the mutual equality of the estimable functions in the partition.

arguments.name: NOMEANS
arguments.description: Specifies not to produce the table of least squares means. This is the default.

arguments.name: OBSMARGINS=
arguments.description: Specifies a potentially different weighting scheme for the computation of LS-means coefficients. The standard LS-means have equal coefficients across classification effects; however, the OM option changes these coefficients to be proportional to those found in the OM-data-set. This adjustment is reasonable when you want your inferences to apply to a population that is not necessarily balanced but has the margins that are observed in OM-data-set.

arguments.name: ODDSRATIO
arguments.description: Requests that LS-mean differences (DIFF, ADJUST= options) are also reported in terms of odds ratios. The ODDSRATIO option is ignored unless you use either the logit, cumulative logit, or generalized logit link function. If you specify the CL or ALPHA= option, confidence intervals for the odds ratios are also computed. These intervals are adjusted for multiplicity when you specify the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: PDIFF
arguments.description: Is the same as the DIFF option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests that least squares means related graphics are produced via ODS Graphics, provided that the ODS GRAPHICS statement has been specified and the plot request does not conflict with other options in the SLICE statement.
arguments.help: PLOT=ALL | ANOMPLOT | BOXPLOT | CONTROLPLOT | DIFFPLOT | DISTPLOT | MEANPLOT | NONE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that the default plots corresponding to this SLICE statement be produced.

arguments.name: ANOMPLOT
arguments.description: Requests an analysis of means display in which least squares means are compared to an average least squares mean.

arguments.name: BOXPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: BOXPLOT<boxplot-options>> Produces box plots of the distribution of the least squares mean or least squares mean differences across a posterior sample. For example, this plot is available in procedures that support a Bayesian analysis through the BAYES statement. A separate box is generated for each estimable function, and all boxes appear on a single graph by default. You can affect the appearance of the box plot graph with the following options: ORIENTATION=VERTICAL|HORIZONTAL ORIENT=VERT|HORIZ specifies the orientation of the boxes. The default is vertical orientation of the box plots. NPANELPOS=number specifies how to break the series of box plots across multiple panels. If the NPANELPOS option is not specified, or if number equals zero, then all box plots are displayed in a single graph; this is the default.

arguments.name: CONTROLPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display in which least squares means are visually compared against a reference level.

arguments.name: DIFFPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display of all pairwise least squares mean differences and their significance. Syntax: DIFFPLOT<(diffplot-options)> You can specify the following diffplot-options: ABS all line segments are shown on the same side of the reference line. NOABS separates comparisons according to the sign of the difference. CENTER marks the center point for each comparison. NOLINES suppresses the display of the line segments that represent the confidence bounds for the differences of the least squares means. The NOLINES option implies the CENTER option.

arguments.name: DISTPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: DISTPLOT<distplot-options> Generates panels of histograms with a kernel density overlaid if the analysis has access to a set of posterior parameter estimates. You can sepcify the following distplot-options in parentheses: BOX|NOBOX controls the display of a horizontal box plot of the estimable function’s distribution across the posterior sample below the graph. The BOX option is enabled by default. HIST|NOHIST controls the display of the histogram of the estimable function’s distribution across the posterior sample. The HIST option is enabled by default. NORMAL|NONORMAL controls the display of a normal density estimate on the graph. The NONORMAL option is enabled by default. KERNEL|NOKERNEL controls the display of a kernel density estimate on the graph. The KERNEL option is enabled by default. NROWS=number specifies the highest number of rows in a panel. The default is 3. NCOLS=number specifies the highest number of columns in a panel. The default is 3. UNPACK unpacks the panel into separate graphics.

arguments.name: MEANPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: MEANPLOT<(meanplot-options)> Requests displays of the least squares means. The following meanplot-options control the display of the least squares means: ASCENDING displays the least squares means in ascending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. CL displays upper and lower confidence limits for the least squares means. By default, 95% limits are drawn. CLBAND displays confidence limits as bands. This option implies the JOIN option. DESCENDING displays the least squares means in descending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. ILINK requests that means (and confidence limits) are displayed on the inverse linked scale. JOIN | CONNECT connects the least squares means with lines. This option is implied by the CLBAND option. SLICEBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to group the means in a single plot. PLOTBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to break interaction plots into separate displays.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the seed for the sampling-based components of the computations for the SLICE statement (for example, chi-bar-square statistics and simulated p-values). number specifies an integer that is used to start the pseudo-random-number generator for the simulation. If you do not specify a seed, or if you specify a value less than or equal to zero, the seed is generated from reading the time of day from the computer clock.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking. The value for number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 1E-4.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN=
arguments.description: Requests that multiple comparison adjustments for the p-values of LS-mean differences be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. Step-down methods increase the power of multiple comparisons by taking advantage of the fact that a p-value is never declared significant unless all smaller p-values are also declared significant. You can specify the following step-down options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment should be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

statements.name: STORE
statements.description: The STORE statement requests that the procedure save the context and results of the statistical analysis. The resulting item store is a binary file format that cannot be modified. The contents of the item store can be processed with the PLM procedure. The item-store-name is a usual one- or two-level SAS name, like the names that are used for SAS data sets. If you specify a one-level name, then the item store resides in the WORK library and is deleted at the end of the SAS session. Since item stores usually are used to perform postprocessing tasks, typical usage specifies a two-level name of the form libname.membername. If an item store by the same name as specified in the STORE statement already exists, the existing store is replaced.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Adds a custom label. When the PLM procedure processes an item store, the label appears in the PROC PLM output along with other identifying information.

statements.name: STRATA
statements.description: The proportional hazards assumption might not be realistic for all data. If so, it might still be reasonable to perform a stratified analysis. The STRATA statement names the variables that determine the stratification. Strata are formed according to the nonmissing values of the STRATA variables unless the MISSING option is specified. In the STRATA statement, variable is a variable with values that are used to determine the strata levels, and list is an optional list of values for a numeric variable. Multiple variables can appear in the STRATA statement.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (‘.’,‘.A’,...,‘.Z’ for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid STRATA variable values.

statements.name: VARIANCE
statements.description: You can specify a probability distribution other than the built-in distributions by using the VARIANCE and DEVIANCE statements. The variable name variable identifies the variance function to the procedure. The expression is used to define the functional dependence on the mean, and it can be any arithmetic expression supported by the DATA step language. You use the automatic variable _MEAN_ to represent the mean in the expression.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement identifies a variable in the input data set to be used as the exponential family dispersion parameter weight for each observation. The exponential family dispersion parameter is divided by the WEIGHT variable value for each observation. This is true regardless of whether the parameter is estimated by the procedure or specified in the MODEL statement with the SCALE= option. It is also true for distributions such as the Poisson and binomial that are not usually defined to have a dispersion parameter. For these distributions, a WEIGHT variable weights the overdispersion parameter, which has the default value of 1. The WEIGHT variable does not have to be an integer; if it is less than or equal to 0 or if it is missing, the corresponding observation is not used.

statements.name: ZEROMODEL
statements.description: The ZEROMODEL statement enables you to perform zero-inflated Poisson regression or zero-inflated negative binomial regression when those respective distributions are specified by the DIST= option in the MODEL statement. The effects in the ZEROMODEL statement consist of explanatory variables or combinations of variables for the zero-inflation probability regression model in a zero-inflated model.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the link function to use in the model.

arguments.name: CLOGLOG
arguments.description: Specifies to use the complementary log-log link function in the model.

arguments.name: LOGIT
arguments.description: Specifies to use the logit link function in the model.

arguments.name: PROBIT
arguments.description: Specifies to use the probit link function in the model.
